intro: Pityrocarpa obliqua subsp. brasiliensis, commonly known as the Brazilian pitier, is a small evergreen tree native to the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. It belongs to the family Olacaceae and is characterized by its dense, dark green foliage and small, fragrant white flowers. The plant produces small, fleshy fruits that are typically consumed by various bird species. It thrives in humid, tropical climates and is often found in secondary forests and along riverbanks. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
